caption: Table 1: Evaluation Accuracy Results on the Test Set. "-" indicates that the evaluation method is not applicable to the problem type. The best performance in each column will be shown in bold, and the second-best performance will be underlined.
description: This table presents the accuracy and F1 scores achieved by various LLMs and evaluation frameworks on a test set designed to assess reasoning capabilities.  The test set included four types of objective questions: multiple choice, math problems, short answer, and classification tasks. The table shows the performance of different methods across all four question types. The best performing method in each category is highlighted in bold, and the second best is underlined.  '-' indicates that a particular method was not applicable to a specific question type.

caption: Table 2: Evaluation Accuracy Results on the Generalization Set. "-" indicates that the evaluation method is not applicable to the problem type. The best performance in each column will be shown in bold, and the second-best performance will be underlined.
description: This table presents the results of evaluating various methods for assessing the correctness of reasoning model outputs on a generalization dataset.  The dataset consists of diverse question types and models not seen during the training phase, testing the models' ability to generalize. The table shows the F1 score and accuracy of each method for four question types (Multiple Choice, Math, Short Answer, Classification) and an overall score.  '-' indicates that a method was not applicable to a specific question type.  The best performance in each column is highlighted in bold, while the second-best is underlined. This allows for a comparison of different evaluation methods' strengths and weaknesses across various question types and their ability to generalize to unseen data.

For each dataset, it shows the number of training and testing samples, the language (Chinese or English), and the license under which the dataset is available.  Note that not all datasets contain exactly 1000 testing samples; some have fewer due to availability or preprocessing.

Note that 'NaN' indicates that the public data for a given model's parameter count is not available.

It shows the number of question-answer pairs generated by each LLM within the training subset of the VAR dataset, providing insight into the representation of various LLMs in the dataset used for training the xVerify model.  This distribution is important in understanding potential biases in the trained model and ensuring the model generalizes effectively across different LLMs.

description: This table presents the detailed evaluation results for all fourteen variations of the xVerify model on the test dataset.  Each model's performance is assessed using four metrics: F1 score and accuracy across four question types (Multiple Choice, Math, Short Answer, and Classification). The highest value for each metric is highlighted in bold, and the second-highest is underlined. This allows for a comprehensive comparison of the different model variants and their effectiveness across various question types.

caption: Table 20: Evaluation Accuracy Results on the Generalization Set: All xVerify Models. The best performance in each column is shown in bold, and the second-best performance is underlined.
description: This table presents the evaluation accuracy results for all 14 xVerify models on the generalization set of the VAR dataset.  The generalization set is designed to evaluate the model's performance on data it hasn't seen during training.  It shows the F1 score and accuracy for each model across four question types: Multiple Choice, Math, Short Answer, and Classification.  The best performing model in each column is highlighted in bold, and the second-best is underlined. This provides a comprehensive assessment of the models' generalization capabilities and robustness across different question types.

caption: Table 21: Running Time Comparison of xVerify Models and Other Judge Models (200 Samples per Question Type). The best performance in each column is shown in bold, and the second-best performance is underlined.
description: This table compares the computational efficiency of various reasoning model evaluation methods, including the proposed xVerify models and other existing judge models.  For four question types (Multiple Choice, Math, Short Answer, Classification), the table presents the average running time in seconds for processing 200 samples using each method.  The fastest running time for each question type is highlighted in bold, while the second-fastest time is underlined. This allows for a direct comparison of the speed and scalability of different evaluation approaches.

description: This table presents the total cost, in USD, associated with using GPT-40 as an evaluation model.  The cost is broken down by question type (Multiple Choice, Math, Short Answer, Classification) and reflects the expense of processing 200 samples per question type. This allows for a comparison of costs across different question types and highlights the overall expense of using GPT-40 for evaluation.
